properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southeast winds of 80 km/h gusting to 100 expected over West Vancouver Island Friday morning. A frontal system that brought strong winds to West Vancouver Island today is departing, and winds are expected to continue to ease somewhat through this evening. However, another system approaching overnight will cause a second round of strong winds late overnight through Friday morning. Winds will gradually ease Friday afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T16:00:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-05T00:01:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4205776633.2021
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (March 3, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Vernon because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath,cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-05T12:24:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-04T20:25:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3033837459.2021
Area: North Okanagan
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southeast winds of 70 km/h are expected Friday morning over the Southern Gulf Islands and sections of Greater Victoria near Haro Strait. A low will approach Vancouver Island tonight. Winds will rise early Friday morning through Haro Strait and the Southern Gulf Islands, before easing near noon. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T15:55:49-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow are expected over the night. These conditions will improve gradually Friday. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 4 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 centimetres are expected by Friday. The snow will ease this evening. Additionally, southerly winds of up to 70 kilometres per hour will combine with snow generating blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 km/h. Locations: the Labrador Straits. Time span: until Friday morning. Remarks: the highest snowfall accumulations will occur inland and over higher terrain. Gusty winds will accompany the snow, giving poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve by Friday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Northerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h combined with air temperatures below -35 will produce extreme wind chill values near -55 tonight in Igloolik and Sanirajak. These wind chill values will moderate slightly throughout the day as temperatures rise but the wind will remain strong. As temperatures cool again overnight, expect these extreme wind chill values to return. Blowing snow conditions are also expected on Friday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T12:37:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-04T20:38:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2911220523.2021
Area: Sanirajak, Igloolik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring over some areas. The combination of clear skies, light winds and melting snow create ideal conditions for fog development. As a result, widespread reduced visibilities were reported over a number of locations in the southern prairies this morning and early this afternoon. With similar conditions forecast for tonight, the fog is expected to redevelop over the region tonight into Friday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL (March 04, 2021 15:00 - Kamloops) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression, or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes; respiratory infections such as COVID-19; pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land- water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-05T16:02:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-05T00:03:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0942334809.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: generally 2 to 5 cm with as much as 10 cm under snow squalls. Locations: West coast from Port Aux Basques to Daniel's Harbour, including the Humber Valley and areas near White Bay. Time span: tonight and part of Friday. Remarks: Snow has tapered to flurries, and several snow squall bands have set up over the west coast. Visibility will be very poor under the squalls, which are expected to meander throughout the night before slowly weakening on Friday. Significant accumulations are expected to ease after Friday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-05T17:00:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-05T02:21:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3176626933.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Green Bay - White Bay, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop Friday morning and end by Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T12:27:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-04T20:28:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0914482327.2021
Area: Cambridge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure system off Cape St. James will track northwards across Haida Gwaii tonight. Ahead of the low, southeast winds of 90 to 110 km/h over Haida Gwaii and the Central Coast will spread to the North Coast this evening. Winds will ease overnight into early Friday morning as the low moves north into the Alaskan Panhandle. Another low pressure centre approaching from the south will move to lie over North Vancouver Island Friday afternoon. Ahead of the low, strong southeast winds will develop over North Vancouver Island and the Central Coast Friday afternoon. Please monitor the forecast as warnings may possibly be re-issued on Friday. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T15:48:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-04T23:49:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4179143959.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

Southeast winds of 90 to 110 km/h over Haida Gwaii and the North Coast will ease late this evening as the low moves north into the Alaskan Panhandle. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
